contents: In 1898, Gilman published a non-fiction book called Women and Economics, (22) one of her most influential works, in which she called for economic independence for women. She also published the non-fiction books The Home: Its Work and Influence (1903) and Does a Man Support His Wife? (1915). She also founded and wrote the feminist monthly magazine The Forerunner from 1909 to 1916. (23A) Some magazines of the time, such as Atlantic Monthly and Harper’s Bazaar, are better known and lasted longer. (23B) Gilman’s magazine offered an alternative magazine for women and encouraged them to fight for changes to society. Although her mother did not allow works of literature, her father loved literature and likely influenced her writing. (24) She published several novels. Her novels included What Diantha Did (1909), The Crux (1911), and Won Over (1913).
